newsitem.title: USA: U.S. says U.N. rights body fails Chinese people.
newsitem.headline: U.S. says U.N. rights body fails Chinese people.

text.p: The United States on Wednesday accused the U.N. Human Rights Commission of failing the people of China by not voting on a resolution criticising Beijing's rights record.

The State Department panned European and other countries that refused to support the resolution and said China had scored only a "Pyrrhic victory" by getting the commission to adopt a no-action motion on the resolution.

At Tuesday's commission meeting in Geneva, a majority of 27 countries supported China's motion with 17 opposing and nine abstaining, sinking the resolution which had been proposed by Denmark and backed by the United States.
It was the seventh year since 1990 that a vote had been prevented on the issue in the 53-member body.
"We regret very much that other democratic countries -- especially many in Europe -- chose not to stand up yesterday," said State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns.
He mentioned no names, but France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and Greece, as well as Japan, Canada and Australia all refrained from from officially co-sponsoring the resolution.

"The real losers in the vote were China's 1.2 billion people," Burns told a news briefing. "The organisation created to discuss their problems living in an authoritarian society, that organisation failed China's people yesterday."

"I suspect this might be a Pyrrhic victory" for China, Burns added. "All of the controversy surrounding this vote only serves to cast international attention on China's human rights record, which is very poor."

The regular exemption of China from discussion in Geneva "threatens to undermine the commission at a time when multilateral discussions of human rights ought to be growing, not limited in the international community," he said.
The U.S. spokesman heaped praise on Denmark for proposing the resolution, a move which has been sharply attacked by Beijing and brought hints of possible commercial retaliation.
"Denmark has been true to a very important international principle. And that is, the universality of human rights all over the world," Burns said.
